A big error I see is argument that goes nowhere.  People have forgotten the central question that is at stake, and are distracted by tangents.  

Ultimately, a simple test of how you've done is presenting the article to others who have read it, and see what they think.

Then finally, it has to be put in context
What other studies are out there?  
Are they better or worse?
Why is this one the one I am prioritizing, or instead, does it fall short?

Then of course, the tricky bit is teasing out whether the data presented support the inferences made. 
 
Is the study confounded?  issues with time zero?  other types of bias?

Are there errors, but that don't matter?

The next Q is: who has the burden of proof?  Is it on the authors to convince me, or am I going to do this till proven otherwise.  And why?  How did that come to be?  Is that framework consistent?

Burden of proof is a key q 
https://t.co/gNpGzizo7t

Does the study apply to your practice-- no matter the results-- is the first key Q

Often the answer is no, and should be acknowledged

Then you need to know a fair bit before diving in.  What is the specific population this question is about.  Does the trial include that population?  What do we normally do outside of the study?  Is the control arm doing that, or deviating?  If it is deviating, in which way?

Before you approach a paper, you should have some idea which category you are in.  

Often in medicine, we are reading with the idea of whether this paper helps or supports recommending some specific medical practice, the...

Should I do this in my practice?

Is this finding concerning enough that we should look into it more or communicate it broadly?

Sometimes it is...
Does the world really work this way?  Is this really the mechanism?

Papers are individual pieces in a broader puzzle

Before I read a paper, I ask myself: what question am I trying to answer?

Often it is: Should I incorporate this drug, device, or surgery into my practice?

Sometimes it is: Should I alter my behavior?

Other-times it is...

How to read a science paper

There are lots of tips and tricks to read certain types of studies, but we seldom discuss how to approach a paper in first place.

I know the reach of @Plenary_Session and we reach far more people than even the top journals in the field. We are dominating Western Europe. Places that are committed to stewardship of financial resources.

But honestly, the truth is, the viewpoint expressed by the writer is dying.

More and more people are getting wise to issues that were not discussed 5 years ago.

It is a lot harder to deconstruct cancer clinical trials, identify what is wrong, persuade other people that it is wrong, and conduct empirical work in this space. And then get it through peer review. And repeat 300 times.

Everyone who works on a trial works hard. But it is not an intellectual feat to enroll patients on a trial that someone else thought of.  

It is not hard to use a medical writer.

This is a true David and Goliath story.

 The current system is due for a dramatic change. Healthcare may undergo the greatest transformation in our lives.

 We cannot spend 30, 40 50% of GDP on health care for products that merely serve to transfer wealth.

The amount of money the industry is throwing to collect billions of dollars from the system is massive. 

The industry has tentacles everywhere. It is taking over academic institutions through partnerships, it is buying off KOLs with money, and it is giving jobs to FDA reviewers

Some of these trials use unethical control arms. I would not randomize my own father to these trials. 

I am sickened that some investigators would randomize patients, when I know they would not randomize their own family.

At the end of the day, all of us rely on cancer trials to make decisions for patients we see in clinic.

@AaronGoodman33

Mantle cell lymphoma trial proposal 

BR plus ibrutinib followed by venetoclax plus ibrutinib vs BR plus ibrutinib followed by ibrutinib. 

Primary endpoint PFS.

Bad clinical trials-- inappropriate control arms, poor post-protocol care, unproven surrogate endpoints, large NI margins-- make a trial incapable of answering a useful clinical question, and are unethical. 

Working hard on such studies doesn't undo that, sadly.

If a trial doesn't have an OS benefit, nor a health related quality of life benefit, and someone does a cost-effectiveness analysis, they have to fabricate QALYs. 

This gives too much analytical flexibility.

III Stylistic things 

Here are a few style things to look for
1.  So many authors who didn't do anything
Don't meet authorship criteria
Enrolling pts doesn't make an author see ICMJE rules https://t.co/f7tmkVsJ3l

8.  If it was a non-inferiority study, is the margin so big you could park a school bus in it?

Was the choice of non-inferiority justified in the first place?

The new drug has to be cheaper, more convenient or less toxic to even run such a trial.

https://t.co/ckZb8pa40h https://t.co/wJeGWl4iZQ

7. Was drug dosing fair?

This is a technical point, best explained in our 2014 JCO paper

https://t.co/XJOGFSaO7g https://t.co/A9hxHEQyv6

6.  Was post-protocol therapy up to the standard of your practice?

This will result in a similar bias as crossover.  Bad post protocol care means downstream endpoints (PFS2/ OS) do not apply to your practice

More to come on this topic...

https://t.co/VDLuvPP6ZK

5.  If the control was investigator choice was it a restricted choice?
or a free, unfettered choice?

This matters
https://t.co/b1JXwQltlZ

4.  If you are testing a drug that has never established efficacy (sip T or vandetanib) you DON'T WANT crossover

IF you are trying to move a drug upfront, including to adjuvant you absolutely DO WANT IT

Read this to understand Xover

https://t.co/SMfCztTwmd

3.  IF they improved HR quality of life, did they measure it properly?

I doubt it!

https://t.co/eZv5UcVMNo

2.  Did they improve PFS or did they actually improve OS?

PFS is a poor predictor of OS across most tumor types...

Even DFS has a lousy correlation, and for the class of drugs presented probably no correlation at all!
https://t.co/sgIJ486zOg

1.  Is the control arm what you would do otherwise?

17% of FDA registration studies use a control arm known to be inferior to best care

"A trial can only change your practice if the control arm is your practice!"
-vp

https://t.co/ZDxEJxtlGh

II Lets turn to randomized trials

BRAVO!

Being older, on more medications, with more rapidly progressive cancer (aka being sicker/ more vulnerable)
